narrative: In the neighborhood I grew up in, Mrs. Baker was the resident cat lady. She had adopted at least twenty – or had given them homes. But she had – a young grandson and back then I was quite the tomboy. And apparently, he was trying to befriend me. I never caught on. Truth is I didn't take to him much because he had – He was a charming lad until you saw his manners. He had poor manners. Goodness gracious he had poor manners. Then he left a note one day saying he was going to run away because she was always nagging about me. She came to my treehouse. Big old tabby cat in tow. I talked her down and said “Well we'll go find him and if we can't locate him, you can – go ahead and call the police if you need to.” I was strategizing. So she took my advice. And we went to where they found his baseball cap – near the old mill and we trailed a bit more and we didn't find a trace. And returned – it was a treehouse club – he was sitting on a branch with a comic book in his hand. He hadn't run away. But – however – that resolved it for that day. But that evening the local sheriff, Officer Dawson said “You better lay low and stay out of sight because that woman never forgets anything once she gets it into her mind.” And I did. I laid low and stayed out of sight. That was the second time.

recalls.5ea20fd571038c119083a8df:
Mrs Baker still lived in my old neighbourhood.  She hoarded all different types of cats and had up to twenty two at any one time.  I recall visiting her whilst her grand son was present.  I remember that he had terrible manners, really, really awful manners. Terrible! But he always helped his gran rescue her cats from beyond our hideout- way beyond the old treehouse.  

One cat got stuck in a treetop where we had a treehouse; we used to spend summers in that treehouse.What fun! He was able to climb to the top, and gently lift cats to safety whilst I could only climb up half way. 

Tomboy, that's what Mrs Baker used to call me. Her shrill tone of "Tomboy", still rings in my ears today, all these years later. Once, the cat lady, (for that what we called her), rang the police! She thought we were stuck in the tree. "What you doing up there, tomboy", she yelled at me whilst on the phone to the police! 

Arriving as though there was a hostage seige, two police cars swooped down the gravelly rough pathways through the tall lofty trees with the sound of the fire brigade ringing out behind them. Everyone came out of their cottages, peering, and mumbling to each other over the fences and pointing at our treehouse. 

And that's all I can remember. I woke up on Mrs Baker's sofa with several cats licking my face, her grand son reading his comic crosslegged on the floor directly opposite me and the police, with concerned frowns, talking and pointing towards me.

What a day that was! It was the second time!

I will paraphrase the story below:

In the neighbourhood I grew up in, Mrs Baker was the local cat lady. She had adopted - or found homes for- twenty cats. But Mrs Baker had a nephew called something, who wanted to make friends with me because I was a Tom Boy. I didn't like him because he had really bad manners - terrible manners. So our protagonist grew up in the same neighbourhood as Mrs. Baker, whose grandson had a crush on our heroine, but which she was blissfully unaware of at the time. One day Mrs Baker comes to our leading lady because her grandson has run away. So the pair go looking for him to no avail, but upon returning to our unnamed narrator's yard they find him sitting in a tree reading a comic book. All's well that ends well you would think, but Mrs Baker casts blame on the Girl With No Name for some such reason and threatens to call the police. So later an intrepid member of local enforcement arrives and leaves our teller of tales with the dubious legal advice of "keeping her head low" for some unfathomable reason, which she inexplicably agrees to do.

This was a chore to read.

recall_scores_completions.5f55c8b78bf0da1a75c991fa:
Alternative version of the story:

In my childhood neighborhood, Mrs. Baker was known for her love of cats. She had taken in at least twenty of them. She also had a grandson who was trying to be my friend, but I didn't really like him because of his poor manners. One day, he left a note saying he was going to run away because Mrs. Baker was always complaining about me. She came to my treehouse with a big tabby cat. I managed to calm her down and suggested that we should look for him and if we couldn't find him, she should call the police. We followed the trail to where his baseball cap was found near the old mill, but we didn't find him. When we returned, he was sitting on a branch of the treehouse with a comic book. He hadn't run away after all. That evening, Officer Dawson, the local sheriff, advised me to stay out of sight because Mrs. Baker never forgets anything. I took his advice and stayed out of sight.

recall_scores_completions.613e6364893dc0edb5e84806:
Alternative version of the story:

In my childhood neighborhood, Mrs. Baker was known for her love of cats. She had taken in at least twenty of them. She also had a grandson who was trying to be my friend, but I didn't really like him because of his poor manners. One day, he left a note saying he was going to run away because Mrs. Baker was always complaining about me. She came to my treehouse with her big tabby cat. I managed to calm her down and suggested that we should look for him and if we couldn't find him, she should call the police. We followed the trail to where his baseball cap was found near the old mill, but we didn't find him. When we returned to the treehouse, he was there reading a comic book. He hadn't run away after all. That evening, Officer Dawson warned me to stay out of sight because Mrs. Baker never forgets anything. I took his advice and stayed out of sight.

recall_scores_completions.6401d8f2d2dd9b8b2a706a20:
Alternative version of the story:

In my childhood neighborhood, Mrs. Baker was known for her love of cats. She had taken in at least twenty of them. She also had a young grandson who was trying to befriend me, but I didn't really like him because of his poor manners. One day, he left a note saying he was going to run away because Mrs. Baker was always nagging about me. She came to my treehouse with a big tabby cat. I managed to calm her down and suggested that we should look for him and if we couldn't find him, she should call the police. We followed the trail to where his baseball cap was found near the old mill, but we didn't find any other trace of him. When we returned, he was sitting on a branch of the treehouse with a comic book. He hadn't run away after all. That evening, Officer Dawson, the local sheriff, advised me to stay out of sight because Mrs. Baker never forgets anything. I took his advice and stayed out of sight. This was the second time something like this had happened.
